Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Mutualism and Parasitism: Entomopathogenic Fungi, Insects, and Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
The use of beneficial microbes that are capable of killing insects represents a more environmentally friendly and sustainable alternative to chemical pesticides. One such microbe is the insect pathogenic fungus Beauveria bassiana that has been commercialized for pest control applications. In addition to their ability to target insects, B. bassiana is also able to form mutualistic associations with plants, resulting in increased plant growth and resistance to insects. This project seeks to understand the biological (genetic and biochemical) basis for the interactions between B. bassiana, insects, and plants. Understanding this process has important implications in beneficial versus pathogenic outcomes, environmental microbiology, and ecosystem balance. Knowledge gained from the proposal can be used to improve the efficacy and safety of using microbes for pest control and plant growth promotion. These interactions present an excellent model system for student laboratory activities relating to fundamental principles of host-parasite biology and evolution, fungal and insect physiology, symbiosis and mutualism, and application of the scientific method. The program provides resources, curriculum development, and citizen science outreach in mycology and entomology for use in K-12 classrooms and beyond. Training at the high school, undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral levels are integrated within the scientific and outreach goals of the project.

Filamentous fungi are a major evolutionary branch of the eukaryotes. Several basal fungal lineages are parasites of invertebrates, and fungal-arthropod interactions represent ancient paradigms for examining pathogenesis. The filamentous fungus Beauveria bassiana is a pathogen of arthropods and forms endophytic relationships with plants. These two seemingly disparate interactions provide a tractable system with which to test and challenge some basic concepts regarding the evolution and persistence of mutualism and parasitism. Our central hypothesis is that in B. bassiana, mutualism and parasitism share underlying molecular determinants. To test this, our research aims to (a) perform a comparative molecular and biochemical analysis between the pathogenic insect interaction and the mutualistic plant interaction, emphasizing the transcriptional and regulatory networks involved, and (b) uncover additional molecular determinants of B. bassiana insect virulence and plant mutualism and examine their respective cross-contributions. This work would provide insight into the factors that contribute to trade-offs that occur during the establishment and/or maintenance of pathogenic versus mutualistic outcomes during organismal interactions. These interactions can be exploited to develop novel means of increasing the pest control and/or plant growth promotion potential of the fungus. Specific knowledge gained from the proposal aid understanding of two broad areas that address how organisms maintain phenotypic plasticity and sensitivity to dramatically different environments: (a) host-pathogen interactions and host-specificity, i.e. the pathways involved in insect virulence, and (b) mutualistic interactions, characterizing the pathways leading to endophyte establishment by the fungus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of fungi to target insects has long been considered a more environmentally friendly, as compared to chemical pesticides, means for the control of various pests. Such examples of microbial biological control are considered “green” technologies, compatible with organic farming practices. Insect pathogenic (entomopathogenic) fungi are natural regulators of insect populations in almost all ecosystems and are under intensive study for the development of safe and effective means for insect control. Of the perhaps more than a million different fungal species on our planet, only a small percentage have evolved the ability to overcome insect defenses and parasitize these organisms. The underlying molecular mechanisms by which these fungi infect target hosts has remained a significant “black box” since the modern discovery of these agents in the 18th century. Goals of this project were to probe molecular determinant of pathogenicity in entomopathogenic fungi, developing and refining models and genetic pathways involved in virulence.

The main insect pathogenic fungal species studied were derived from the Beauveria and Metarhizium (Ascomycota) genera that are typically broad host range insect pathogens, although some are more restricted in their host range. Uniquely, in the past several decades, these fungi have also been recognized as being able to form mutualistic relationships with certain plants. In addition, although these fungi are pathogens of insects, they do not infect vertebrates. Our research has focused on uncovering the molecular and biochemical mechanisms employed by the fungus to (a) parasitize insect hosts, and (b) form mutualistic associations with plants. This research is important because it can lead to new paradigms applicable to microbial pathogen evolution, disease dissemination, and plant-microbe interactions. Our research has increased our basic knowledge in several critical areas including: (1) expanding information concerning underlying molecular pathways important for (fungal) survival, stress response and virulence. Many of these genes and pathways are shared from microbes to man. Importantly, knowledge derived from project outcomes can be used to increase develop rational designs strategies for increasing the efficacy and safety of biological control applications in the targeting insect pests.

Specific project outputs have included defining the molecular genetics of how the fungus attaches to, degrades, and penetrates the insect cuticle. Our data has supported new ideas concerning the cuticle as a significant barrier to infection, and that the insect can detect and respond to spores of the fungus on the surface before they have germinated, even if they are ultimately unable to stop the infection. We have characterized important parts of the infection process, including characterization of antimicrobial compounds used by the fungus to inhibit competing microbes, pathways used by the fungus to suppress host immune responses, and stress response pathways widely distributed in eukaryotes. Results from the project have led to the characterization of the functions of transcription factors, cell wall biosynthetic genes, and other genes that contribute to the ability of the fungus to adapt to different environmental conditions including the insect host and plant niches.

            Project outcomes have contributed to molecular and biochemical characterizations applicable to fungal virulence, mutualism, and fungal-insect-plant interactions.  The project has provided educational and training opportunities for students at many levels including high school (summer internships) and undergraduate (summer and academic semester) students. The project has supported and involved graduate students, post-baccalaureate, and post-doctoral/research scientist levels. Students at various levels have also participated in various career and personal enhancement activities including seminar and poster presentations, grant writing workshops, and ethics in science seminars. Summer and year-long internships were also support for continuing education of teachers, focusing on introducing the study of fungi (mycology) and insects (entomology) at the K-12 levels. Data and informational dissemination have occurred through national and international meetings, peer-reviewed publications, and news articles and videos.
